name: Santiago de Compostela
fun_fact: Fun fact: Santiago is the endpoint of the Camino de Santiago pilgrimage - after walking hundreds of miles, pilgrims traditionally celebrate with pulpo a la gallega and local wine, a reward that's been the same for over 1,000 years.

hero_dishes.name: Pulpo a la Gallega
hero_dishes.description: Tender octopus cooked in copper pots, sliced and served on wooden plates with paprika, olive oil, and sea salt
hero_dishes.origin_story: Galician octopus is legendary across Spain. Cooked in traditional copper pots (the metal matters), the octopus becomes incredibly tender. Served on wooden plates (tradition, not presentation), it's seasoned simply - good olive oil, Spanish paprika, coarse sea salt. The dish is so important that specialized restaurants (pulper칤as) serve only octopus.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Los Sobrinos del Padre Benito (rustic, locally famous), Pulper칤a os Concheiros (authentic pulper칤a), El Mes칩n Do Pulpo (10-minute walk from center - worth it), Pulperia Fuentes (Conxo neighborhood)

hero_dishes.name: Tarta de Santiago
hero_dishes.description: Moist almond cake covered with powdered sugar featuring the cross of Santiago imprint
hero_dishes.origin_story: This ancient cake recipe uses only almonds, eggs, and sugar - no flour. The cross of St. James stenciled in powdered sugar identifies it as authentic. Created centuries ago by nuns and still made the same way. After completing the Camino pilgrimage, eating this cake is traditional celebration.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every caf칠 and bakery in Santiago, especially good paired with coffee between sightseeing stops

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Galician Seafood
hero_dishes.description: Vieiras (scallops), percebes (goose barnacles), zamburi침as, whatever came from Galicia's coast that morning
hero_dishes.origin_story: Galicia's Atlantic coastline is Spain's seafood capital. The cold waters create exceptional flavor. Pilgrims arriving in Santiago have celebrated with Galicia's bounty for over 1,000 years. The scallop shell (vieira) became the Camino's symbol because pilgrims ate so many.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mercado de Abastos (essential market where chefs shop for fresh seafood), Abastos 2.0 (near market - modern twist on tradition), Orixe (modern local tradition)

hero_dishes.name: Empanada Gallega
hero_dishes.description: Large savory pie filled with tuna, cod, or meat - Galicia's portable feast
hero_dishes.origin_story: These substantial pies were pilgrims' traveling food - portable, filling, delicious cold or hot. The golden crust hides generous fillings of Galician tuna, cod, or meat with peppers and onions. Every bakery has its own recipe.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bakeries throughout Santiago, Mercado de Abastos, traditional restaurants

signature_drinks.name: Albari침o Wine
signature_drinks.description: Crisp, aromatic white wine from R칤as Baixas region - Galicia's signature wine
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served slightly chilled with pulpo and seafood - the acidity cuts through richness perfectly. Albari침o is one of Spain's finest white wines. Locals pair it religiously with octopus and shellfish. Many pulper칤as serve it by the glass.

signature_drinks.name: Queimada
signature_drinks.description: Flaming Galician firewater made with aguardiente, sugar, lemon peel, and coffee beans - set on fire during ritual
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Reserved for special occasions and celebrations. The ritual involves reciting an incantation while the liquor burns in a clay pot. It's theatrical, traditional, and powerful - meant to ward off evil spirits while warming the soul.
